title: Kha Tutorial Series
description: KHA, a portable creative framework written in Haxe. For source code, go to the github repo. To support these videos, pop to Lewis Leptons patreon page

videos.title: Episode 000 - intro to haxe, kha & future plans
videos.description:
so here we are, aiming down another path of things to do. this time, its 'kha', a portable multimedia framework written in haxe.

we talk about haxe, kha & kode studio, plus delve into what we will be doing in future episodes.

read more about haxe here: http://haxe.org
read more about kha & kode studio here: http://kha.tech
check out haxelib here: http://lib.haxe.org

videos.title: Episode 001 - setting up everything
videos.description:
so we know what kha is. why dont we get one & start installing some thing?

we first download haxe, install it, then setup haxelib [which holds our installed libraries]. we then install the github version of kha through haxelib, install node.js & lastly grab a copy of kode studio.

for mac users, we also delve into showing hidden items. so we can then find our haxelib location. plus it shows our node location as well.

videos.title: Episode 002 - updating kha
videos.description:
so whilst having kha is great, we need to take care of it through updates.

we go through 2 ways to update kha. we look at using haxelib first [which can be used for all libraries], then move onto using git pull to grab updates to the submodules

videos.title: Episode 003 - init kha project plus extras
videos.description:
finally we get to venture into the wild. or at least, stand on the edge.

we look at initialising the project to bring in some files, Main.hx & Project.hx, including 'khafile.js'.
we look at how things work & then change the kha path, to allow use of the git version of kha.

lastly we go a bit deeper & edit the init.js inside kode studio for future projects, also to make it easier for new users.

gists of my settings, hotkeys & other groovy things can be found here:
https://gist.github.com/lewislepton

videos.title: Episode 004 - loading an image
videos.description:
finally... finally we get to actually do some code with kha.

we create a new project folder, init our project with our custom init process, then change to the git version of kha.
also looking at 2 new classes to use - 'Image' & 'Assets' to load the image into project. lastly looking at 2 ways we can draw the image on screen.

videos.title: Episode 005 - drawing shapes
videos.description:
we go to the dance-floor & bust out some shapes.

we setup our project using our custom init.js & go on to start making a rectangle & then a line. then we add some color to them.
finishing off by getting circles in as well to draw on screen.

videos.description:
here we look back at images & try something else.

we load up our project & look at 'drawScaledImage();' with our graphics. we change the width & the height of the image.
lastly we look at a different way to load images.

videos.title: Episode 007 - font & text
videos.description:
we can show something else other than sexy images, thats text.

we start our project & make sure our font is in our asset folder. importing a new class, 'import kha.Font'. we also show 2 different ways into how we can use the font.

font used within this tutorial:
https://www.fontsquirrel.com/fonts/open-sans

videos.title: Episode 008 - sound
videos.description:
we break out of our silence & bring in sound.

we introduce 3 new classes*, 'Sound', 'Audio' & 'AudioChannel'. we set things up so we can load a sound [.wav] in to the channel then play it.
we also then break down the code for something a little easier to read.
lastly we finish off by talking about extra functions inside AudioChannel.

*i said 'libraries' in the video, but i did mean to say 'classes'

videos.title: Episode 009 - graphics
videos.description:
using framebuffer to draw shapes can be all well & good, but its not great.

we look at a new class called 'Graphics' to draw shapes on screen.
we then create a function to hold in our graphics & lastly call it into our render function to draw on screen.
this will help in our future tutorials & projects.
'Graphics' also can apply to drawing images as well.

videos.title: Episode 010 - keyboard
videos.description:
its ok to just type with things & run. but we need some interaction - here comes the keyboard.

we get two new classes in - 'Key' & 'Keyboard'. then we make 2 new functions 'onKeyDown' & 'onKeyUp'.
lastly we make sure that it can be read in to print our presses.

*there has been a change with the keyboard, more so 'key'. now it uses something called 'keycode' instead of 'key'. makes things a little bit easier & shorter to type.
first update video is here:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZltHQfMCLyw
then has another update here:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BD0Pk_mlW6k

all source code has been updated for these changes

videos.title: Episode 011 - mouse
videos.description:
where is a keyboard without a mouse?

we start by putting a new class in our memory banks - 'Mouse'. moving onto creating three new functions - 'onMouseDown', 'onMouseUp' & 'onMouseMove'.
lastly printing off the data these can spit out by making sure we can call the mouse in.

videos.title: Episode 012 - gamepad
videos.description:
whilst keyboard & mouse get most of the glory. the shining star goes to the gamepad.

we look at importing a new class - 'Gamepad' & proceed to create two MEGA functions for our 'Axis' & 'Buttons' for the controller.
we then plug in our 'xbox one' controller and start printing things out on screen.

lastly we step it up a notch & introduce two more controllers to use within our projects, without drivers. its super awesome.

xbox controller driver needed for mac users
https://github.com/360Controller/360Controller

USB NES controller
http://www.gearbest.com/mice-keyboards/pp_261726.html

videos.title: Episode 013 - build
videos.description:
so we cant really do much with debug applications. we go to build a project.

we create a super simple project. head to our terminal/command line & see how we can build a html5 application, then move onto building an xcode project & lastly how we can build a native application using terminal/command line.

this just delves into desktop based applications & not ios/android yet. those will happen. but later on when we do touch based devices.

videos.title: Episode 014 - classes
videos.description:
its all well & good stuffing everything into one file. but its not good practice - we look at classes.

starting off we create a simple project & start right away by creating a new file/class called 'Rect.hx'.
we go into that file and let it become a class that can draw a rectangle.
we go back to our 'Project.hx' & call it in & make it render on screen.
we go even further & create a folder, making this hierarchy levelling by sticking the 'Rect.hx' inside it & do some edits so its work perfectly.

videos.title: Episode 015 - color
videos.description:
we can stick to being a blank canvas, but thats no fun. we look at using color.

we create 2 classes that can draw a 64x64 square for each. we then load in 'Color' & show how a class can affect each other.
then we move onto extending 'Color' & show we can use float & byte values for deeper color manipulation.

videos.title: Episode 016 - update
videos.description:
we can stay still, but that can be boring. we look at update.

we create a simple project by creating a new class called 'Block', create some variables that can access the X/Y of a rectangle.
we call it with our project & lastly access the X/Y to update the location of the rectangle at 60 frames per second.

videos.title: Episode 017 - translate
videos.description:
we can shift things on screen using the entities X/Y, but we can also move things another way - we look at translate.

we first get a basic project up, and make a new 'Block' class that renders a block on screen. we then make sure we have imported a new kha class called 'FastMatrix3'. this will help in moving the X/Y on screen.
lastly we making sure the translate is then working with the block class & render it on screen.

i also talk about that Kode Studio has had some minor updates done to the separate github repo[s], its not a full release yet. but it finally puts the debug console at the bottom. woooo
go to here for the mac version:
https://github.com/KTXSoftware/KodeStudio.app
for the windows version go here:
https://github.com/KTXSoftware/KodeStudio-win32
linux has not yet been updated with those minor updates. but you are not missing much else.

also the useful snippets i use can be found here:
https://gist.github.com/lewislepton/808d6d2bef1c1c71cf76

also please excuse my voices oddness, my chest is a bit tight due to helping a friend move house. my lungs seemed to be filled with mould from the damp in the room of the house they were living in. but will be better very soon ;)

videos.title: Episode 018 - create entities using for loops
videos.description:
we can stick by making file after file, sure. but we wont. here we look at creating entities using for loops.

starting by creating a new project, a new class called 'Block'. we move onto implementing arrays within our project.
we make sure that our array will affect the drawing of it, then move on to make the mouse draw multiple instances of the 'Block' class using the left mouse button.
lastly, we also make sure we can then delete as well using the right mouse button.

videos.title: Episode 019 - timer
videos.description:
we can still make things move without update - we look at timers.

with a new project, we create a new 'Block' class. then in our main file, we set up our 'System' to allow using the system owns time when running.
then setting up a duff block that can be used as a expanding bar, for loading, or for health. we also set up our timer to create blocks on screen.
lastly we get the keyboard involved to reset it.

videos.title: Episode 020 - player movement
videos.description:
we have drawn blocks, we have even put keyboard stuff in. lets smash them together - we look at player movement.

we create a new project & make a new class which has some bools in amongst also a speed float.
we head back into our main class & instantly start bringing our keyboard controls. then lastly make sure we can update our movement, so when keys are pressed, the player moves.

videos.title: Episode 021 - bounds
videos.description:
we make our player move, but not too far. we look at bounds.

straight away we duplicate our 20th episode project & rename it. we get right into the 'Player' & start adding in width/height & making sure we are 'getting' those as well.
we then head into our main project & start making a new function which will hold our bounds, so our player always stays within our screen bounds.

videos.description:
we build upon what we have done from the 20th & 21st episode - we introduce gamepad movement for the player.

we duplicate the 21st project & instantly import the 'Gamepad' class, then move on & make a new function called 'onGamepadAxis', which we then put in our d-pad controls.
we lastly then show the changes for using analog controls properly.

we have been fighting on the front line too long - we look at backbuffer.

we create a new project, then create a new 'Block' class. we then import 4 classes & proceed to setup our backbuffer.
lastly we change it up a bit with our output rendering & make sure we are using our sexy new backbuffer & can then even scale the render on screen.

our screen can stay at 800x600, but thats cack - we look at window options.

we duplicate our previous project '023_backbuffer' & head right to our 'khafile.js' & introduce a few cool things to change our width & height of our output window.

videos.title: Episode 025 - mouse position
videos.description:
so while the keyboard can have all the fun for the masses by moving the player - we look at mouse positioning.

we create a new project & new 'Block' class with a simple setup. we then import the kha 'Mouse' class & make sure its setup within our 'new' function.
we lastly create a 'onMouseMove' function which will handle the major points of the movement.

videos.description:
we have opened many things, images, classes, but what about webpages?

start by creating a new project & import ing a few things. we then move on to creating a string pointing to a URL. then we create an on key down function that helps us open a webpage.

lastly we export the project to a HTML5 project & open it in a web browser, finishing it off by pressing the key we set to open the webpage

videos.title: Episode 079 - for loop draw
videos.description:
we have drawn, but we can use for loops to draw things in a creative way.

start by creating a new project & right away heading to our render & coding a for loop that makes 32 rectangles draw from left to right.
we then create a for loop in a for loop to draw a grid.

lastly we import some classes & code one last for loop to draw rectangles that spring around on screen.

videos.title: Episode 080 - center position
videos.description:
we work with object all the time, but originally they start from the top left. we look to put our start point in the center of an object.

starting by creating a new project & a reusable Entity class. putting an x, y, width & height inside.
we then code out a ShapeObject that uses the Entity class. next, we make an ImageObject class which also uses the Entity class & make sure that the image affects the width & height.
our last class is FontObject also using the Entity class, using the fonts string & size to affect the width & height.

we then create a grid to show how the objects are rendered using the center point.

videos.title: Episode 081 - delete array entity
videos.description:
we have deleted with for loops. but we do something much better using while loops.

starting with a new project, we copy our entity class from our previous '080_centerPosition' project & updated it.
then making a player class which extends with our entity class.

coding an array of players, then 3 functions: one to create, one to delete & the last to make a type of border our player array will delete itself once passed.

we then lastly update our movement, render & make sure we can use our mouse to create & delete players in the array.
now we can delete any entity in any order no matter what, making this a much better option for handling deletion of entities
